            Facts
            
                
                    White wakerobin is the largest-flowered trillium in New England, where it is native to portions of western New England and persisting or spreading from cultivation elsewhere. It also has an exceptionally long-lived flower, remaining open and fertile for two to three weeks. This has been shown to increase the probability of visitation by the large long-tongued bees (Bombus) that are its most effective pollinators. The roots of white wakerobin were used for medicinal purposes by several Native American tribes. Occasional stripes or markings on the petals are attributed to infection with mycoplasma (parasitic bacteria).

                Forests, talus and rocky slopes
